official-title.#text: To amend the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to invest in innovation for education.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Education and the Workforce

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text: Investing in Innovation for Education Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended by adding at the end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Title IV of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/t:IV
usc/20/7101/etseq

text.#text: The purposes of this part are to—
fund the identification, development, evaluation, and expansion of innovative, evidence-based practices, programs, and strategies in order to significantly—
increase student academic achievement and decrease achievement gaps;
increase secondary school graduation rates;
increase college enrollment rates, rates of college persistence, and rates of attainment of other post-secondary credentials;
improve teacher and principal effectiveness or retention of highly effective teachers or principals; and
increase the identification and dissemination of innovative educational strategies in rural areas; and
support the rapid development, expansion, and adoption of tools and resources that improve the efficiency, effectiveness, or pace of adoption of such educational practices, programs, and strategies.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:4402/ss:b
Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:4408

text.#text: In awarding grants under this section, the
improve early learning outcomes and academic connections between early learning and elementary school;
support college access, persistence, and success;
support family and community engagement;
address the unique learning needs of students with disabilities or English language learners;
support the effective use of education technology to improve teaching and learning;
improve the teaching and learning of science, technology, engineering, computing, or mathematics;
serve schools in rural local educational agencies;
train teachers or principals to adopt and implement college and career ready standards;
develop alternative career pathways or differentiated school staffing models for effective teachers or principals to expand their impact on student learning;
train or support principals or teacher leaders, including teacher leaders preparing for principal roles;
support, improve, or develop any other area of school innovation, as determined by the
address the learning needs of Indian, Native American, Alaska Native, or migrant children in school.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall set standards for the quality of evidence that an eligible entity shall provide to demonstrate that the activities the eligible entity proposes to carry out with grant funds under this section are likely to succeed in improving student outcomes or outcomes on other performance measures. These standards may include any of the following:

text.#text: The

Strong evidence that the activities proposed by the eligible entity will have a statistically significant effect on student academic achievement, student growth, graduation rates, or outcomes on other performance measures.
Moderate evidence that the activities proposed by the eligible entity will improve student academic achievement, student growth, graduation rates, or outcomes on other performance measures.

Evidence of promise or a strong theory that the activities proposed by the eligible entity will improve student academic achievement, student growth, graduation rates, or outcomes on other performance measures.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:4403

text.#text: Each eligible entity that receives a grant under
shall use the grant funds to address, at a minimum, one of the following areas of school innovations:
Improving the effectiveness and distribution of teachers or principals.
Strengthening the use of data to improve teaching and learning.

Providing high-quality instruction based on rigorous standards that build toward college and career readiness and measuring students' mastery using high-quality assessments aligned to those standards.
Turning around the lowest-performing schools.
Supporting the effective use of technology to improve teaching or principals and learning, including training teachers or principals in the innovative use of technology.
Any other area of school innovation, as determined by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:4406

text.#text: shall use those funds to develop or expand strategies to improve the performance of high-need students on the performance measures described in

text.#text: In this part:
The term
a local educational agency;
an educational service agencies; or
a nonprofit organization in partnership with a local educational agency or consortium of schools.
The term
that serves not fewer than 10,000 children from families with incomes below the poverty line;
for which not less than 20 percent of the children served by the agency are from families with incomes below the poverty line; or
that is in the highest quartile of local educational agencies in the State, based on student poverty.
The term
an elementary school or middle school in which not less than 50 percent of the enrolled students are children eligible for free or reduced price lunch under the
